sentence.content: The Booker Prize is Britain&apost;s literary event of the year, guaranteed to boost sales of the chosen novel after the award announcement Oct. 16, and dinner in London&apost;s ancient Guildhall.

(CD 16))))))))) (, ,) (CC and) (NP (NP (NN dinner)) (PP (IN in) (NP (NP (NNP London) (POS 's)) (JJ ancient) (NNP Guildhall)))))) (. .)))

sentence.content: The prize to the author is a check for 20,000 pounds (nearly $38,000), sponsored by Booker, an international food and agriculture business.

sentence.content: ``British publishers are very secretive about their sales but we know that when Thomas Keneally won it in 1982 for `Schindler&apost;s Ark,&apost; his publishers, who had printed 15,000 copies, sold 75,000 over the next 23 weeks,&apost;&apost; said Christine Shaw of Book Trust.

sentence.content: ``The prize has become internationally known, and the worldwide demand for the winning book, in English and translations, is spectacular,&apost;&apost; said Shaw.

sentence.content: The prize was first awarded in 1969 after talks between Booker and the Publishers&apost; Association on the need for a significant literary award to encourage and reward good writing.

sentence.content: A management committee of authors, booksellers, librarians and the sponsors chooses a jury of five: a writer or two, an academic, a politician interested in literature and a literary editor or critic.

sentence.content: As public debate rages over who&apost;s in, who&apost;s out and who might win, with bookmakers across the country calling the odds, the jurors meet again and finally select the winner on the afternoon of announcement day.
